It's going to be a question of who shows up, plain and simple. That's why buzz will be so important tomorrow. You must be a registered Republican to participate, but you can register at your caucus location with proof of address and a valid ID. And, as Ivanka Trump points out in her how-to-caucus video, Republicans will be casting a secret ballot-- once. No need to plan your evening around convincing the neighbors you don't know that well to stand in your candidate's group, and no need to worry about those same folks remembering who you supported if your allegiance might be termed impetuous. This argues for a strong Trump showing, particularly if social media gets cranked up ("Print your cell bill and go! #Showing up for Trump"). Lines of people bearing utility bills aren't likely to be Cruz supporters; his campaign touts a strong [traditional] ground game. With this said, the weather will be a factor locally. Rain and snow will be moving into western Iowa by caucus time. Might that be enough to dampen the enthusiasm of the less well-organized? It probably won't matter in Des Moines and points east, but is enough to keep me under 60%.

To win the caucuses, your supporters have to attend them and stick around and be reasonably coherent or at least persistent.  Statewide polls in a state that runs precinct-level caucuses are at best misleading.  Many people have preferences in or predictions about boxing matches. Somewhat fewer watch the matches on television, especially if something else comes up, unless they feel strongly about it.  A smaller number yet get in their cars, drive to the venue, buy tickets, and watch the match.  Even fewer think it would be fun to work the corner for one of the participants.  Attending a caucus is more like the last of these; answering a poll question is more like the first.

"Ted Cruz sits atop the Republican pack in Iowa with just 19 days until the caucuses, but Donald Trump is just 3 percentage points behind, a new Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics Iowa Poll shows.

But likely caucusgoers' opinions of the ultraconservative Texas U.S. senator remain sky high (76 percent view him favorably).
...
In third place with likely GOP caucusgoers is Marco Rubio, with 12 percent, and Ben Carson is huddled close behind at 11 percent. Those are precarious perches, because a majority of their supporters say they could still be persuaded to support someone else, said Iowa Poll pollster J. Ann Selzer.
...
A majority of likely caucusgoers, 56 percent, could change their minds about their first-place choice or still do not have a first choice, the poll finds.
...
The Iowa Poll of 500 likely Republican caucusgoers was conducted Jan. 7-10 by Selzer & Co. of Des Moines. The margin of error is plus or minus 4.4 percentage points.
...
While Cruz's lead of 10 percentage points on Trump in early December has whittled to 3 points, underlying data show Cruz to be well-positioned. The constitutional lawyer is the second-choice pick for more voters than any other candidate. And he attracts almost half the electorate when percentages of first- and second-choice preferences are combined, Selzer noted.
...
Cruz may be boxed in tactically when it comes to attacks: 75 percent of likely caucusgoers view his decision generally to avoid criticizing Trump as a favorable trait."

We've had a remarkably mild winter so far in the Upper Midwest-- a few cool snaps and more rain than snow-- which facilitates retail campaigning and has probably kept a few struggling candidates in the mix. Gov. Huckabee, for example, completed the Iowa Long March today (http://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/elections/presidential/caucus/2016/01/07/mike-huckabee-99th-county-campaign-iowa-caucus/78281080/). His timing was excellent; the season's first Arctic Blast is forecast to commence on Saturday. The Register's campaign tracker listed 25 Huckabee events between January 2 and now, second only to the 28 Sen. Cruz planned between January 4 and 9. Clearly, both men consider Iowa vital to their future success. But will either be able to quickly lock up a room come caucus night? Evangelical participants-- the target audience for both-- have several self-identified candidates from which to choose, and will see them regularly in the next two weeks: Cruz, Huckabee, Dr. Carson (13 events listed between January 6 and 11) and Sen. Santorum (11 events listed between January 7 and 12). Supporters may work long and hard to come to a consensus on February 1st.

Granted, the Democrats are more complicated -- not to mention more fun -- but even so, the caucus is a process.  In the previously posted "Donald Trumpâ€™s Strongest Support" ( http://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/31/upshot/donald-trumps-strongest-supporters-a-certain-kind-of-democrat.html?_r=0 ) is that Iowa isn't full of ardent Trump supporters. The second thing is the lack of political savvy. I have worked with these guys, and have had them as neighbors. We have engaged in political discussion. The one thing I have noticed is that even though they are registered to vote, they don't. (That last statement is based upon some post election polling, and also checking on the voter rolls. When getting out the vote, I have checked to see when the last time neighbors have voted, and am amazed how many do not.) And this is in the general elections -- caucuses are a higher bar. First, precincts are not necessarily the normal polling place. If new to the process, it is best to have someone tell you when and where to show up. And if you are late, the doors are closed and you don't get in. Once you are in, you have to stick around for awhile for the vote. There is a social component to the caucus, which is why the evangelical voters turn out.

When faced with multiple choices, none of which are well differentiated, people go with the person/entity they know.  Trump's TV presence trumps his policies.  Absent an issue appearing that differentiated the candidates and allows other candidates to become known, Trump wins.  Or if the menu had fewer choices (Trump vs. 1 or 2) then Trump would have a larger issue.  The size of the field (number of choices) and lack of differentiating factors (explainable to the masses) leads to an irrationally rational choice based on familiarity.  This is essentially the same phenomenon that gives us multiple Bush / Clinton presidencies.

I welcome any comments on how I arrived at this conclusion and on how it could be improved.
1) Polls are a prediction of an event if it were held today.  The problem is that this event is
four months away.  I had a bit of trouble in finding old polls, but I did find:
2012 Santorum won - but in Oct 2011 he was at 3% in Iowa.  2008 Huckabee won - in Oct 2007
he was tied for second at 13%.  I believe that Bush was leading at this stage in 2000 and went
on to win, but I think that his lead was larger than Trump's. 
2) I also looked at the Democrats to see what had happened - Obama won Iowa in 2008 and
was at 22% on October 2007.  Kerry won in 2004 and he was at 9% at this stage.  (I am simply
using it to see how indicative presidential polls are at this stage.)
3) Santorum with just 3% at this stage in 2012 has gone on to win Iowa.   So in looking at the RCP polls 
averages, I'll eliminate Pataki, Graham, Santorum, Christie, Gilmore, and Kasich as they are all polling 
below 3%.
4) That leaves nine - Trump, Carson, Fiorina, Cruz, Rubio, Bush, Huckabee, Jindal, and Paul.  
All things being equal 100 divided by 9 is an 11% chance.   Leads do mean something historically
so Trump has a better chance than someone polling much lower.  I think there is also a chance that someone 
(Paul?) will drop out of the race by then and/or fall further in the polls.   So I will give Trump 1 
out of 8 based on someone dropping out/falling further and a bump to 1 out of 6 based on his lead.

I think the people talking about "ground game " in Iowa make an excellent point, which would be applicable in just about any other year. But the way the caucuses are set up, a group of people discuss who their precinct should endorse. If it turns out that the person with the best ground game is, say, Bush, it's almost certain that all non-Bush delegates will coalesce around a single candidate to stop him. I think there's a good chance that candidate would be Trump. Put another way, this year, candidates with the resources to play a good ground game may have a disadvantage precisely because they are able to command those resources. Such is anti-establishment politics.

Iowa is all about the ground game. You need not just enthusiastic morons and high poll numbers, but hard-working precinct-level organization to get folks to come to the caucuses and do as they're told.  Trump shows no evidence of understanding this. You can win later events at wholesale, but Iowa is all retail.  Far as I can tell and am told, Trump has wildly inadequate local organization. (Bonus: He is also not likely to win New Hampshire, as those folks take their responsibility to screen out the crazies fairly seriously.) (Free prediction: He will be out of the running by April or so and will announce as an independent, despite having no organization and no idea how to win as one.)
